no_coverage.title: Likely Not Covered
no_coverage.summary: Liability-only policies typically don't cover glass damage.
no_coverage.explanation: Unfortunately, if you only have liability coverage (which covers damage you cause to others), your policy will not cover damage to your own windshield. Your Options: • Pay out of pocket: Repairs cost $50-$150, replacements $200-$1,000+ • Upgrade your policy: Add comprehensive coverage for future incidents • Check for exceptions: Some states or policies have special glass provisions
nextSteps: Check if repair is cheaper than replacement

zero_deductible_state.title: Likely Fully Covered!
zero_deductible_state.summary: Your state has zero-deductible glass coverage laws.
zero_deductible_state.explanation: Good news! You live in a state with zero-deductible glass coverage laws. This means your comprehensive insurance should cover your windshield repair or replacement with no out-of-pocket cost. Important Notes: • Your insurance company cannot raise your rates for a glass claim in these states • You should still verify coverage with your insurer • Choose a shop in your insurance network to avoid billing issues
nextSteps: Call your insurance company to confirm

repair_likely_covered.title: Repair Likely Fully Covered
repair_likely_covered.summary: Most insurance policies cover chip/crack repairs with no deductible.
repair_likely_covered.explanation: Most comprehensive insurance policies cover windshield repairs (not replacements) with zero deductible. This is because insurance companies save money by encouraging repair over replacement. Why This Matters: • Repairs cost $50-$150 out of pocket, but $0 with insurance • No rate increase for repair claims (typically) • Faster service (30 minutes vs 2+ hours) • Preserves your original factory windshield seal
nextSteps: Call insurance to confirm zero-deductible repair

replacement_check_deductible.title: Likely Covered, But Check Your Deductible
replacement_check_deductible.summary: Replacement is usually covered, but you may owe your deductible.
replacement_check_deductible.explanation: If you have comprehensive coverage, your windshield replacement should be covered. However, you will likely need to pay your comprehensive deductible first. Deductible Considerations: • Low deductible ($0-$100): Claim makes sense • Medium deductible ($250-$500): Compare to out-of-pocket cost • High deductible ($500+): May be cheaper to pay yourself Rate Impact: Some insurers may raise your rates for a comprehensive claim. Ask before filing.

check_policy.title: Check Your Policy Details
check_policy.summary: You may have coverage, but need to verify with your insurer.
check_policy.explanation: Based on your answers, you may have glass coverage, but the details are unclear. The best step is to call your insurance company directly and ask: Key Questions to Ask: • "Do I have comprehensive coverage?" • "Does my policy cover glass damage?" • "What is my glass or comprehensive deductible?" • "Will a glass claim increase my rates?" • "Do you have a preferred shop network?"
